review.title: Towards Detection of Bottlenecks in Modular Systems
review.abstract: The paper describes some basic approaches to detection of bottlenecks in composite (modular) systems. The following basic system bottlenecks detection problems are examined: (1) traditional quality management approaches (Pareto chart based method, multicriteria analysis as selection of Pareto-efficient points, and/or multicriteria ranking), (2) selection of critical system elements (critical components/modules, critical component interconnection), (3) selection of interconnected system components as composite system faults (via clique-based fusion), (4) critical elements (e.g., nodes) in networks, and (5) predictive detection of system bottlenecks (detection of system components based on forecasting of their parameters). Here, heuristic solving schemes are used. Numerical examples illustrate the approaches.

sections.text: ar Xiv: 130 6.01 28v1 [cs.AI] 1J un2 013Towards Detection of Bottlenecks in Modular Systems Sh. Levin. The paper describes some basic approaches to detecting bottlenecks in composite systems (modular). It examines the following basic problems in detecting bottlenecks in the system: (1) traditional approaches to quality management (pareto diagram-based method, multi-criteria analysis as a selection of particle-efficient points and / or multi-criteria ranking), (2) selection of critical system elements (critical components / modules, critical component networking), (3) selection of networked system components as composite system errors (via clique-based fusion), (4) critical elements (e.g. nodes) in networks and (5) predictive detection of system bottlenecks (detection of system components based on prediction of their parameters).

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: In recent decades, the importance of modular (multi-component) systems has increased (e.g. org, [3,7,10,13,16,23,29,30]). This paper describes approaches to detecting bottlenecks in composite (modular) systems. It assumes (Fig. 1): 1. The hierarchical modular system under consideration can be presented as a morphological structure (e.g. [15,16,18,22]) or as a network. 2. The following system elements are examined as bottlenecks: (i) system components (or a system component failure), (ii) networking between system components (compatibility), (iii) group of system components (or a group of system errors), (iv) group of interconnected system components (or related system components).

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text: The paper describes basic approaches to identifying bottlenecks in composite (modular) systems. In general, system bottlenecks detection must be used as the first stage of the system improvement / development process. The approaches described for detecting system bottlenecks are an important preliminary stage for the analysis and new design (redesign) of various systems. On the other hand, the approaches considered for detecting system bottlenecks are very close to system test procedures (e.g. multifunction system tests [20,26]). In the future, it may be useful to consider the following research guidelines: (1) Examination of various applications in the real world; (2) Examination of multi-level frameworks for detecting system bottlenecks; (3) Examination of system bottlenecks as system components (s) "trajectories"; (4) Additional Examination of bottlenecks in hierarchical (multi-layer) networks, for example: (i) Identification of system bottlenecks (5)

metadata.abstractText: The paper describes some basic approaches to detection of bottlenecks in composite (modular) systems. The following basic system bottlenecks detection problems are examined: (1) traditional quality management approaches (Pareto chart based method, multicriteria analysis as selection of Pareto-efficient points, and/or multicriteria ranking), (2) selection of critical system elements (critical components/modules, critical component interconnection), (3) selection of interconnected system components as composite system faults (via clique-based fusion), (4) critical elements (e.g., nodes) in networks, and (5) predictive detection of system bottlenecks (detection of system components based on forecasting of their parameters). Here, heuristic solving schemes are used. Numerical examples illustrate the approaches.
